body: Blimey, the lua script seems to have tabs and spaces mixed. I'll take care of that after hearing some more comments.
Looks like people like this direction of change. I'll take time and get what pchote said done.

I've mentioned this in a few places, and it is likely too ambitious for this first PR, but IMO the ideal layout for our Lua/AI integration (which i'd like us to eventually move towards) would be to have:

* One lua file for the global AI strategy (base building, attack waves, etc).
* Team types defined in yaml, with a `CustomLogic: teamtype.lua` field referencing a file per team that contains functions that are called on team creation / disbanding / tick (e.g. your apc + flamer rush).
* Have a context table that stores shared data between the global and team functions, so that e.g. the global AI code can recall teams to defend the base.

I'm not asking you to implement this here, but it would be great if you could keep this in mind when working through my request above.

I'd honestly have that pchote-AI-proposal as a completely separate AI class with this PR having side-by-side along with it (and along with DummyAI). Sure, the proposal has more depth and allows for more options, but will also require more work for the modders while HackyAI is quite simple in terms of YAML setup and would only require Lua for special units (like transports, spies or engineers) anyway.

This will come in handy for sure. HackyAI is great for starters, but get's too limiting once you want to do more advanced tactics with AI.

Going to watch there this is going as we currently are experimenting with lua based AI for Crystallized Doom.

And here I was just thinking of something like this.  I was planning on doing some AI scripting tests later but has no idea how to tap into the Hacky AI from the Lua script since I'd never seen any examples of it in the missions or custom maps.

In any event I hope this gets into the game since it might be useful down the road for those of us that want to script the Hacky AI with additional functions.

I'll see if I can help as well since I've got a ton of my own ideas like Island Hopping and Unreachable Location Access that I'm thinking of working on. :) Keep up the good work too.

Also side note the Fort Lonestar AI has the Crate search code if you want to add that to your AI. :P

I want to hear comments about commit https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/12949/commits/913833cebd15ffb46701e3e628c57fa5d2dc4a6b

- I could have created an independent copy of AIScriptContext, ScriptAIActorProperties and ScriptAIPlayerProperties. Then, substantial portions of existing Lua API must be copy and pasted, as most of them has potential to be used by the AI scripters. It will double the cost of Lua API maintenance as fixing bug in one side must be mirrored to the other side.
- Instead, I broke the seal of ScriptContext so that current Lua API can be shared with inherited AIScriptContext.
- Then at the interface between Lua and C#, safety can be checked by checking if Context is AIScriptContext at runtime. This is bad for performance.
- Instead, like what happens for ExposedForDestroyedActors, I introduced ExposedForAIScript. In constructor of AIScriptContext, the commands will be filtered and only the ones that have ExposedForAIScript will be exposed.
- Still there is a little problem. In ResourceProperties.cs, there is a ReadOnlyCash and Cash property. I thought giving cash to the AI for cheating can cause game to crash. I introduced a read only version for AI scripting. Maybe I can modify Cash's set() to check if it is AIScriptContext and reject the action there instead.
I believe you should just expose (if it wasn't exposed yet) GiveCash and TakeCash to Lua. I can imagine that some missions would also rely on it - TS/RA2 IIRC had them exposed.
@GraionDilach Maps and missions are unaffected. (not 100% tested but hopefully). Current problem is that Im not sure which traits are safe for from AI induced desyncs.
I think I got per-function AISafety property. If people like this change, I'll do some more work to move Teams and taskforces into YAML.
The fix commits should be squashed to sanitize history.
I'll defer squashes a little bit since current PR even has Ludicrous speed in mod.yaml too!

All squashed into one. Still, I have a question. In mod.yaml, there are default hacky AIs and there's one I've introduced to test the Lua augmented AI. What shall I do with those? Should I remove the new one and enable scripting for others?

About the AI Names, i think you should rename the new AI to Scripted AI from Scripted Turtle AI, we don't have others yet. In future we can probably ditch out the Hacky AIs on vanilla mods and use Lua for all, get rid of Scripted prefix and back to current names.

Also your usage of comments looks a bit too much to me. I'm not sure about other stuff, but at least "# These are build at safer positions." on `ai.yaml` is unnecessary.

I haven't had a chance to look at this properly, but I suspect there will be trouble when you run a scripted AI on a scripted map, so that there are multiple script contexts.

The actor bindings run through [this function](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/bleed/OpenRA.Game/Actor.cs#L382) that is lazily initialized (for performance reasons) the first time a script tries to interact with an actor.  I'm not sure what will happen when you later try to interact with the actor from another script context, but i'm expecting that the result won't be good.
Looks like we'd need multiple instances of luaInterface so that the actor can be manipulated from any contexts.

I've added a test map called Fort Lonestar Test. (which will be removed at final squash)
Play it with Hacky Scripted AI.
I made a modification to hacky ai so that the initial E1's it creates self heal by 10 every second. (for testing purpose). Then in the map trigger, I made all E1, E2, E3s HP is set to 25 every 10 seconds.
Both are in effect without crash.

In current commit, when one of AI's initial E1s die, it can't heal and will cause Lua script error but that's scripting bug not engine bug.
Any thoughts on hastag or WrappableMembers yet :) ? I think I got other comments addressed.
I'm not sure how this whole commit, request thing works etc. But i do hope you guys make A.I a bigger thing with this mod. They seem bland and very weak at current state.

@chazechad I think AI in this commit is weak too. However, my focus in this commit is to make AI do build order, unit building and prove that bots can do more complex task than hunting enemy (hunting is pretty much all hacky AI can do as of now). My hope is that with commit merged, since Lua is intended for people at "modder levels", they can start contributing to AI improvement, which wasn't possible with C# hard coded Hacky AI.

AI test is now as separate mod now. It could be merged into official ra mod later, but for now, I don't like how my 5x speed setup gets into the commit and interfere with official ra mod.

https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/12949/commits/9d37118d8eba28638a5dd0cd8f090c835e411137#diff-e9b25ee6bdc0322762567826ef993465R54
I've modified binding filters. AIScriptContext is now checked as high level as possible. Predicate is passed down to the lower levels instead. Also, tagging actors as occupied from the script side is now more natural, rather than previous tagging method (which turned out to be not working as the actors weren't IsTaggable!).

https://github.com/forcecore/OpenRA/commit/c265027f8f065c2602cca3b07d17b812801f08b7#diff-262611b9e40de7482f6e5d523b9d6f33R26

I don't like how HackyAI is resolved from the actor properties but this seems to be the most sensible solution, as HackyAI is in Mods.Common name space and AIScriptContext is in OpenRA.Game name space. I tried moving AIScriptContext to Mods.Common as HackyAIScriptContext but that didn't turn out very well as that makes (lua) Runtime member inaccessible. Passing HackyAI to AIScriptContext constructor doesn't work either as mentioned above, AIScriptContext is located in OpenRA.Game, the core engine part not Mods.Common.
Well possible scenario. In missions there won't be HackyAI + modders will request some HackyAI features to be exposed to Lua, giving need for AI only functions. I am for the new tagging.
Mission only / AI only script attribute introduced. Properties without specification binds to both contexts.
Keep it up, this looks like it'll turn out well later. :)
I've incorporated this PR into my mod to check anything goes wrong.

So far, good. Apart from it is really difficult to debug Lua and there are many pitfalls in Lua interfaces, like Hunt() canceling itself and Produce() fails when the prerequisites aren't there when called (or even during the production). I think this should be pulled as early as possible so that modders will start reporting/complaining about Lua API.

It is unfortunate, but we need to keep this (and most of the rest of the PR queue) on the backburner for the time being.  The current version of bleed has several major engine changes that need more time and work to converge on something we can release.  We simply don't have enough experienced manpower to complete https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/milestone/23 *and* review other PRs.

The milestone needs to be our top priority because we can't ship any new OpenRA versions until the work being tracked there is finished.  Merging other big changes before then risks slipping the deadline even further, so we need to balance the risk vs reward for each case.
Needs rebase.

Rebased for bleed.
Compiles.
Works? Dunno. The example ai_test mod got out of date. Removed it.

LuaHacky thing in my mod has moved on. HackyAI in bleed has moved on too.
I'm beginning to care less.

This is taking longer than an engineering paper journal article peer review process.
Dah shouldn't have removed the outdated mod, it contained an example Lua script. It's gone now.
